Hi All,
Pardon the cross posting on the forums, but I am looking for info o=
n a
rather unusual sword.
A friend has owned this sword for many years that=
 I quite fancy. Very
long nagasa, and appears to be o-surige. Has an o-kiss=
aki, and well
cut naginata-type hi. Nakago looks to be around shinshinto pe=
riod, but
just my novice opinion.
What is odd about the sword (apart from t=
he fact that it looks like a
nagamaki blade made into a katana) is the insc=
ription on the blade on
both sides.
Sorry for the bad pics. Only had 5 minu=
tes to take these limited pics
today, and had to do them in segments in bad=
 light. The sword has a
beefy blade, with some weight to it, and the hi are=
 very nicely cut.
Hamon is not very visible in the pics, but is clearly vis=
ible in
person, and quite wide suguha.
Anyways, a translation done very lon=
g ago supposedly came up with
something along the lines of "I am so sharp, =
I can cut clouds" but I
have strong doubts about this.
Looking for a transl=
ation from anyone please.
What would the significance of the inscription be=
, and could it be a
gift sword or a dedication, or a commission blade? Fitt=
ings are nice
tachi mounts, and the blade doesn't appear to my humble eyes =
to be a
junk sword. Original nagasa would be estimated at well over 28"
ori=
ginally.

A post on another forum gave the following helpful info:
"This in=
scription is most likely a reference to something found in
Chinese literatu=
re or Chinese mythology. I say this because its not
made up of typical Japa=
nese compounds and doesn't resemble any
Buddhist phrases that one typically=
 sees on swords. I think the 3rd
and 4th kanji combine to form the word "li=
ghtning" in Chinese
(somebody correct me if I'm wrong), but the word for li=
ghtning in
Japanese uses a different kanji. Read kanji-for-kanji as Japanes=
e you
end up with a jumble of word roots. The kanji on the left are
&#21091=
;光閃電鞭刀輝破浮雲
W=
hen translated it reads; sword, light, lightning (taking the Chinese
readin=
g), whip, katana, brilliant, rupture, floating, and cloud. It
doesn't take =
much imagination to read this as you have stated in your
post ("Lightning-f=
lashing, cloud-rupturing sword"). But as I say its
probably a direct refere=
nce to a particular myth or poem, which
contains this exact phrase. The own=
er would then have the added bonus
of appearing quite erudite and well-read=
 in the Chinese classics. I
think samurai were keen on secret societies and=
 this inscription may
have some significance in this context as well. In an=
y event its not a
phrase that you would encounter in Japanese, which leads =
me to believe
it's a Chinese literary reference."
